newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan's opposition says don't condemn soldier.
newsitem.headline: Jordan's opposition says don't condemn soldier.

text.p: Jordan's parliamentary opposition urged the government on Monday to stop "condemning and criminalising" a Jordanian soldier who shot dead seven Israeli schoolgirls last week.

The opposition members said in a statement that no Islamic rulings could sanction the killing of children, but that it occurred against the backdrop of "extreme provocation" of Israel's decision to build a settlement in Arab East Jerusalem.
The soldier, army driver Ahmed Mousa al-Daqamsa, shot dead seven teenage Israeli schoolgirls on Thursday on Jordanian territory leased to Israel under a 1994 peace treaty.

"The opposition calls on the government...to stop its condemnation and criminalisation...and attacks on the rights of this Jordanian," the statement said. "They should give him a chance to defend himself."
King Hussein has expressed shame at what he described as a vile act, and Prime Minister Abdul-Karim al-Kabariti said the soldier would be "prosecuted to the full extent of the law".
"The statements from the government ... contravene the constitution and basis of law which state that the accused is innocent until proven guilty," the statement said.
